","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2bc0edb7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2fc0edb7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"67c0edb7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961972","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a3c0edb7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"efc0edb7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961977","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"47c0edb7db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961958","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Module Practical tasks","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Each module will involve 3 different sections: 1) Self Reflection, 2) Resources and activities, and 3) Evaluation of module learning. You will be asked to complete several practical tasks in each Module. The tasks may include (but are not limited to) reading materials, watching videos, completing worksheets, writing forum posts, writing reflections, completing a knowledge quiz. There are 3 possible scores for each consecutive pair (Weeks 1&2, 3&4, 6&7, 8&9) of Modules:

? 10%: You must complete all tasks to receive this score.

? 5%: You will receive this score if you do not satisfactorily complete 1 – 3 tasks.

? 0%: You will receive this score if you miss 4 or more tasks.

Therefore, if you complete all of the tasks using reasonable effort (see the ‘fair-go’ policy below) then you are guaranteed a minimum score of 40% in this course. The deadline for each consecutive pair of Modules will be 10pm on Sunday of the second module in the pair. Note that there are no extensions for these deadlines.

IMPORTANT: Please note the following three important points.

1. When you go into a Module you will see there are several tasks you need to complete, which we know can look a bit overwhelming. However, please keep in mind that several of these tasks simply require you to click on a link to read some text or to watch a video. Thus, these tasks will be marked as complete just by you interacting with the material (e.g., when you click on a link to watch a video that task will be marked as complete).

2. Although the participation and practical work is not formally graded, there is a ‘fair-go’ policy. According to this fair-go policy, you must put reasonable effort into completing these tasks. If you do not put reasonable effort into a task then we will mark that task as incomplete. Examples of violating the fair-go policy include: (a) not following the task instructions (e.g., you were asked to discuss “X” but you discussed something else, you were asked to write in sentences but you used dot points, etc.), (b) not meeting the minimum required for the task (e.g., you were asked to write a minimum of 75 words but you only write 60), and (c) not putting in suitable effort (e.g., you were asked how you would explain a certain strategy to a friend so that s/he could use it and your explanation is only a 4-word sentence). Thus, the fair-go policy is not about always being right and perfect, but rather about following instructions and demonstrating reasonable effort when completing these tasks.

3. There are no extensions for Module Practical Tasks. The Modules open well in advance of the deadlines so please plan accordingly and do not leave completing the tasks until the last minute.

Moving through the Modules

As mentioned previously, each module has sections on 1) Self Reflection, 2) Resources and activities, and 3) Evaluation of module learning. Each module also has an additional section called Further Resources. The Further Resources section contains materials that students may be interested in exploring to further their understanding, however students are not required to engage with the materials in this section.

Although one goal of this course is to help you with your “surviving” and “thriving” here at university, we also expect the tools and strategies you learn to be useful in your personal and professional life. Thus, as you are moving through the modules it is also important to think about how you may be able to use what you are learning in other situations. Relatedly, sometimes you may find a particular task or module is currently not highly relevant to your life; for example, you may not feel you are currently experiencing much stress and so you may be unsure how to complete a task that asks you about stress. In these cases it is important to put yourself in someone else’s shoes (e.g., we likely all know people who are stressed), and/or think about past situations that are relevant to what you are being asked to do (e.g., we have all likely been stressed at some point; how did you feel/cope/etc. when that happened?).

In general, the Modules are designed for students to work through the sections in the order they appear. There are some important aspects of how the modules work that you need to be aware of:

  • When you first start a Module you will only have access to the Self Reflection section. To unlock the other sections of a module you must complete the Self Reflection section.
  • The Modules are set so that they need to be completed in order. Thus, Moodle will not allow you to move on to the next Module until you have completed the last section (i.e., the Test your Module Learning section) of the previous Module.

It is important to keep in mind that the Module schedule provided only tells you when modules become available. That is, once a Module becomes available you cannot access it unless you have completed the previous Module. Thus, you want to make sure that you work through each Module in a timely manner.

contentlets.keywords: psychology,psychological literacy,well-being,psychological science,self knowledge,evidence-based strategies,self-management,surviving and thriving
contentlets.description: The subject matter of this course covers theories and research regarding the science of self-optimisation (e.g. time management, study skills, emotional regulation), and provides students with opportunities to improve self-management capacity that could help them survive, and thrive, in university and beyond. Self-management is the capacity to work effectively toward meaning goals, and to be flexible in the face of setbacks. The course is open to all students as a general education offering, and its online delivery mode will allow for some time/place flexibility while learning.
contentlets.title: Psychological Science of Wellbeing

This course provides students with knowledge of the characteristics of the scientific approach in general, and experimental methodology, design and data analysis in psychology in particular. It provides a comprehensive foundation in critical thinking, enabling students to design and plan research, conduct basic statistical analysis, scrutinise and critically evaluate published research, discriminate between evidence-based information and pseudoscience, and effectively communicate statistical and research data in variety of formats and contexts. A significant amount of the course content will be delivered online via Moodle (https://student.unsw.edu.au/moodle), allowing students to interact with course material and assess their knowledge at their own pace.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2f11747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961968","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Participation/preparation activities","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Continuous Assessment- Online quizzes, Online Tutorials and Research Participation.

Online weekly quizzes (10%): These quizzes provide you with an opportunity to revise and deepen your knowledge of key concepts in the course. 10 weekly-revision quizzes will be available in weeks 1-10.You will be awarded 1% for completing each quiz with a score of 65% or greater by Sunday 11:59pm the week it is released. You may take the quiz as many times as you like, your highest attempt will count towards your grade. The quizzes will remain open for revision until the final exam.  Feedback is provided online via Moodle upon completion of each quiz.

Online Tutorials (5%): These activities are designed to prepare you for face-to-face tutorials, in order to get the marks for completing these activities (1% per each set of online tutorial activities) you will have to complete these activities by Monday 9am the following week. Late completions will be possible but will not earn marks.  Feedback is provided online via Moodle upon completion of each online tutorial.

Research participation (5%): You will be able to participate in psychological research within the School for 5 points (1 hour of participation equates to 1 point).  By participating in ongoing research you learn first-hand about the ways in which research in psychology is conducted, and can appreciate the application of the concepts that you encounter in lectures and tutorials. You also find out about theories and areas of investigation that are beyond those you study in the course, giving you an insight into the research that academics conduct in the School of Psychology. In this sense, you are very much contributing to the advancement of psychological science. Clearly, the study of human behaviour cannot progress without humans to observe and we ask that you act in a responsible way to ensure your research participation provides usable data to researchers within our school. Every researcher is under the general supervision of an Ethics committee, and is therefore required to satisfy certain conditions to ensure ethical practice during an experiment (e.g., to provide information regarding the nature and aims of the study). There is no compulsion to participate in any particular study and it is quite in order to decline to participate after an explanation of what is involved has been given.

This 2 hour exam will be a combination of multiple choice and short answer questions. The questions will cover the material covered in weeks 1-10 (inclusive) in lectures, online lecture activities and weekly quizzes, as well as suggested readings.  The exam will take place during the UNSW exam period.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1b11747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"2311747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5711747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9311747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"d311747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d711747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"db11747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"df11747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3211347bdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research study critique","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

You will be given a study that you will have to critically evaluate for its methodological soundness. Through open ended questions you will be asked to identify the research question, independent and dependent variables; confounding variables etc. The submitted piece will be 500 words (maximum).  Feedback will be provided online via Moodle within 10 days of the assignment due date.

Length: 500 words.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1b11747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"2311747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5711747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9311747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"d311747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d711747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"db11747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"df11747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8f11747bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961925","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

You will be required to write a full research report (1500 words) based on data provided to you. You will receive more information about the report in the assessment sheet and tutorials.  Feedback will be provided online via Moodle within 10 days of the assignment due date.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6396ad77dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid term test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

A Mid-term Test will be held in the Tuesday lecture in Week 7. This test is open book and will cover material from the first half of the course (lectures weeks 1-4; tutorials and labs weeks 2-5). Please bring your calculator and notes from tutorials. There will be no supplementary test for students who miss the test.

Feedback will be provided within 10 working days of the due date and will be made available online via Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1796ad77dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2b96ad77dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"eb96ad77dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4f96ad77dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961939","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"45","description":"

The Final Exam will be two hours and will be closed book (but relevant formulae and statistical tables will be provided). The exam will contain data analysis questions, and both short-answer and multiple-choice questions. The data analysis questions will require you to do some limited hand calculations and interpret output from SPSS. The emphasis of the exam is on your understanding of inferential procedures and research methodology issues as well as their practical application. Please bring your calculator to the exam.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1796ad77dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2b96ad77dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6796ad77dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"eb96ad77dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5f96ad77dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

The Assignment is compulsory and is to be submitted through the Turnitin link on the Moodle page by midnight on the Friday of Week 9. The assignment question will be released in Week 5 and will involve analysis, interpretation and presentation of data.

Feedback will be provided within 10 working days of the due date and will be made available online via Turnitin.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1796ad77dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2b96ad77dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6796ad77dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"eb96ad77dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8796ad77dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"SPSS Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

An SPSS Test will be held in the Computing Lab in Week 10 at your normal lab time. This test is compulsory and will involve analysing and interpreting data and SPSS output. Please bring your calculator and notes from tutorials.

Feedback will be provided within 10 working days of the due date and will be made available online via Moodle.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PSYC2061","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC2061 - Social and Developmental Psychology","description":"

This course introduces students to empirical research, methodology and theories in the fields of social and developmental psychology.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a5dec1dedb166010be4672f5f3961909","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"45","description":"

The final exam will be 2 hours and scheduled during the exam period. The exam will consist of 60 multiple choice questions and will be conducted on Moodle. Half of the questions will relate to the Developmental psychology section of the course and half will relate to the Social Psychology and First Nations content.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"65de45dedb166010be4672f5f396193c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6dde45dedb166010be4672f5f396193a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"42de45dedb166010be4672f5f3961952","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Tutorial preparation & participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Throughout the course there are online activities that are designed to prepare students to engage in face-to-face tutorials, to practice self-management skills and to engage with course content. There are 5 marks to be earned by completing the activities that are directly related to tutorial content. Students should complete these tutorial prep exercises BEFORE they attend their tutorial; preparation marks will be credited if each activity is completed by Sunday 11:59pm in Weeks 2, 4, 5, 7, and 10.

\n

An additional 5 marks can be earned by completing participation activities. These activities give students an opportunity to practice self-management skills that are key to success and wellbeing and relate to looking forward (goal setting, time management), looking back (reflecting on performance/feedback) and engaging with content (using evidence-based study strategies, reading critically, applying knowledge). To earn the full 5% available, students should complete at least 5 activities (out of a total of 16). There will be at least one activity due each week and students may choose which ones to engage with, depending on their personal study goals.

\n

There will be examples posted throughout the term to show you what level of engagement is expected. If you receive an incomplete for one activity, just try another one. There are no extensions for participation activities; you must complete by 11:59pm Sunday in the week that an activity is due to receive the grade.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"61de45dedb166010be4672f5f396193a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"65de45dedb166010be4672f5f396193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6dde45dedb166010be4672f5f396193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6dde45dedb166010be4672f5f396193c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"79de45dedb166010be4672f5f396194e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Developmental media report and peer review","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"45","description":"

This assessment will be released in in Week 2. Students will write a short article (word limit= 500 words) for the Sydney Morning Herald about a new research finding in developmental or social psychology, producing a high-quality piece of science journalism. Students will use the characteristics of good vs. poor journalism that were generated in Week 2 tutorials as a guide; these will be used to construct the marking criteria for this assignment. Students will submit a draft of their article for peer review in Week 4. Students will provide peer reviews to three of their colleagues and engage in self assessment. Feedback will be due in Week 5 and can be used to revise and improve work prior to final submission in Week 8. In total, this assignment is worth 45% of your final grade (35% media article, 10% peer reviews).

This course introduces fundamental principles in human perception and cognition, such as sensory coding, perceptual organisation, attention, and memory. Tutorials provide an introduction to psychophysical methods, experimental approaches to the study of cognitive processes, and the application of findings in society.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PSYC2081","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC2081 - Learning and Physiological Psychology","description":"

This course focuses on the behavioural and physiological basis of elementary learning processes. These include: learning about relations between events (Pavlovian conditioning), learning about relations between one’s behaviour and events (Instrumental conditioning), how these forms of learning control behaviours and their involvement in addiction, attachment and schizophrenia. The course emphasises psychological explanations of behaviour but also seeks to ground these processes in neurobiology.

The online quiz consists of 20 MCQ questions based on the lectures from the previous weeks. You must gain a mark of 80% or above and complete the quiz by Sunday 11:59pm the week it is released in order to be awarded the 1% for each quiz. You may take the quiz as many times as you like.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0623e6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a96190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0e23a6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5223e6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9e23e6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a961912","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c623e6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a96190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"da23e6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a961915","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3d23a6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619cf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

You will be required to submit a complete Research Report (2000 words) including: Introduction, Method, Results, Discussion and References. You should include your introduction and method section from Assessment 1. You should use the feedback from Assessment 1 and make any suggested changes to your Introduction and method section and consider the feedback when writing your results and discussion.  The absolute final day for submission is 10 days from the assessment due date.  Failure to submit your assessment by this day will results in a mark of 0 for the assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0623e6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a96190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0e23a6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5223e6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9e23e6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a961912","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c623e6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a96190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"da23e6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a961915","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4623a6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619d4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"45","description":"

The 2 hour final exam consists of 80 multiple choice questions. It will cover all content from the course with a focus on lecture material.  This exam will be scheduled during the UNSW exam period.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0623e6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a96190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0e23a6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5223e6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9e23e6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a961912","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c623e6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a96190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"da23e6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a961915","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4623a6a3dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619e5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Report introduction & method and peer review","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Assessment 1: Report introduction and method and peer review (continuous assessment)

Part A: You will be required to write the introduction and method section (1300 words) of a Research Report based on an online Experiment run in Week 1.  Information about the experiment and background research will be discussed in the Week 1 tutorial. Additional resources will be available in the Week 4 Online tutorial. The absolute final day for submission is 10 days from the assessment due date.  Failure to submit your assessment by this day will results in a mark of 0 for the assessment.  The mark you recieve for Part A will contribute 10% to your overall mark.  

Part B: For this assessment you will be required to review the work of two other students in the course. The reviews will be anonymous, and you will be given a rubric to assess the written work. This is designed to help you develop an understanding of the criteria for marking scientific writing and to help you develop skills at effective communication. You must complete two reviews of other students by the assigned deadline to be awarded the grade for this assessment. You will receive 5% of the course mark for completing the review tasks.

contentlets.description: This course focuses on the behavioural and physiological basis of elementary learning processes. These include: learning about relations between events (Pavlovian conditioning), learning about relations between one’s behaviour and events (Instrumental conditioning), how these forms of learning control behaviours and their involvement in addiction, attachment and schizophrenia. The course emphasises psychological explanations of behaviour but also seeks to ground these processes in neurobiology.
contentlets.title: Learning and Physiological Psychology

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC2101 - Assessment, Personality and Psychopathology","description":"

This course is an introduction to psychological assessment, personality, and psychopathology. The assessment portion of the course will include key concepts related to personality and intelligence testing. The psychopathology portion of the course is an introduction to the study of maladaptive behaviour and mental disorders. The course will provide an overview of common mental disorders, including anxiety, mood, eating, childhood, and psychotic disorders. Emphasis will be placed on diagnostic criteria, contemporary theories of psychopathology, and empirically supported approaches to treating mental disorders.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8962b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a961987","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial preparation","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"5","description":"

Before each tutorial class every student must complete the associated online module as pre-work (where indicated, as detailed in the course schedule online activities column) and study the reading(s) set for that tutorial class. Video case presentations will also be used to illustrate the major clinical features of selected disorders. Students are expected to actively participate in discussions concerning the set readings and the video presentations. The tutorial preparation mark is based on completion of the designated online pre-work.  Marks and feedback will be provided within 10 working days of the due date.  Students will be able to use the marks and feedback from components of this assessment to gauge their performance in the course prior to the census date.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3062b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"3462b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"7062b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7862b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"8d62b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b462b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f062b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2062b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a961943","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

The final exam will be a multiple-choice test that takes place online during the official examination period. This exam will cover material presented in the lectures, tutorials, tutorial readings, and tutorial preparation online modules

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3062b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"3462b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"7062b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7862b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b462b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f062b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6862b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a961947","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Short answer questions","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will receive two short answer questions on designated topics in psychopathology in Week 2. Students will submit short written answers (500 and 750 words) to these questions by 11.59pm on Friday of Week 4 in MS Word version via Turnitin. The short answer assessment must also be emailed in electronic form directly to the tutor. Short answer assessments will not be accepted after Friday of Week 6 and will receive a mark of 0.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3062b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"3462b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"7062b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7862b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"8d62b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b462b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f062b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6862b1b7db315c50eb6b147a3a961958","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will be paired through random assignment to give a 10-minute oral presentation in one tutorial class, based on the reading set for that tutorial class. Assigned presentation partners and readings will be announced in the first tutorial.  Marks and feedback will be returned within 10 working days of the presentation.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PSYC3001","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC3001 - Research Methods 3","description":"

The course deals with various experimental designs involving between- and within-subjects factors, for which some form of analysis of variance is an appropriate method of data analysis. Particular emphasis is placed on the use of simultaneous test procedures and simultaneous confidence intervals to produce coherent analyses of data from complex experiments.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a321db6fdbf1d850eb6b147a3a961996","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-session test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

A 90 minute mid-session test worth 20% of the course mark will be held during the Wednesday lecture in Week 6. The test will be on Topics 1-8. Statistical tables will be provided. You are required to provide your own UNSW approved calculator.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2b21db6fdbf1d850eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6721db6fdbf1d850eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a321db6fdbf1d850eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ef21db6fdbf1d850eb6b147a3a961985","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5321db6fdbf1d850eb6b147a3a961952","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

An assignment worth 20% of the course mark is due by 11pm Monday of Week 9 and is to be submitted to the Turnitin link on Moodle. This exercise will cover material drawn from Topics 9 - 13. The exercise will be set in Week 6 and will require you, among other things, to design an experiment, construct a set of hypothetical data with certain properties, and use PSY statistical program to analyse your hypothetical data.

A two-hour Final Exam worth 60% of your course mark will be held during the T1 Examination period. Statistical tables will be provided, you are required to provide your own UNSW approved calculator.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PSYC3011","attributes":[{"name":"Capstone","code":"capstone","description":"This course is normally taken toward the end of a program and it typically incorporates a research project or examination on a broader context of the study."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC3011 - Research and Applications of Psychology","description":"

The primary purpose of this course is to provide a capstone experience for students undertaking a major in psychology, regardless of their degree program. The integrated acquisition of the graduate capabilities, as partly indicated through assessment of the learning outcomes, comprises ‘psychological literacy’. This capstone course offers an opportunity to explicitly integrate material from the entire psychology major (through the use of the Career Development Portfolio assessment, in particular). 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7d3604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619f7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

This will be held in the final examination period, and will be two hours in duration. The location will be announced in lectures. The examination will be multiple choice and short essay format. A more detailed guide to content will be provided at the end of the session.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"713604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"753604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"753604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7d3604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7d3604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7d3604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619fb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0e3644b5db6a5c50358b403c3a961920","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Career development portfoilio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

This assignment will be approximately 1500 words. You will be asked to:

  • identify a desired career pathway
  • create a LinkedIn profile
  • identify a person in a career position to which you aspire
  • conduct an informational interview with that person
  • write a job advertisement for that person’s position
  • write a CV, cover letter, and interview preparation notes to apply for that job

See the assignment handout for more detail.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"713604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"753604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"753604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7d3604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7d3604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7d3604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619fb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7d3604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619fd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Collaborative research assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"22","description":"

The aim of this assessment is to: (1) familiarise you with the process of designing research in applied settings, (2) familiarise you with a particular reporting style, and help you acquire the basics of effective and efficient scientific communication, (3) emphasise the development of your information literacy skills, as well as promoting critical thinking, and (4) provide you with a supported collaborative learning experience.

Throughout the semester your will collaborate as a group to design an intervention to address a specific psychological issue. You will propose to test your hypothesis by investigating the needs of the target population, developing an intervention, and a means for evaluating the effectiveness of the intervention. Part A is designed to get you started thinking about your target population for Part B; you will also peer review other groups. For Part B, each group will present their research proposal to the class. Normally, all group members will receive the same mark. Peer evaluation of your group members’ contributions will be used to moderate individual marks for this assignment. See the assignment handouts for more detail.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"713604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"753604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"753604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7d3604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7d3604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7d3604b5db6a5c50358b403c3a9619fb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a23644b5db6a5c50358b403c3a961930","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Four quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"8","description":"

Four short quizzes (2% each) are to be completed in weeks 2, 4, 7 and 9, will make up 8% of the mark for this course. These will be presented across the term testing the lecture, online lecture, and tutorial content. These are open-book tests, and you will be encouraged to complete the tests during the scheduled face-to-face group time. This way you will be able to talk about the content being assessed, engage with the information more deeply than you might when simply selecting a choice by yourself, and establish rapport with your group members. Furthermore, being on campus together will ensure a more reliable internet connection than doing tests separately at home. Internet connection problems will not be accepted as an excuse for not submitting.

contentlets.description: The primary purpose of this course is to provide a capstone experience for students undertaking a major in psychology, regardless of their degree program. The integrated acquisition of the graduate capabilities, as partly indicated through assessment of the learning outcomes, comprises ‘psychological literacy’. This capstone course offers an opportunity to explicitly integrate material from the entire psychology major (through the use of the Career Development Portfolio assessment, in particular).
contentlets.title: Research and Applications of Psychology

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PSYC3051","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC3051 - Physiological Psychology","description":"

This course provides an overview of the neuroscience of learning and memory. Emphasis is placed on contemporary theories and approaches including the role of interactions between environmental events, synapses and genes. Topics include: appetitive and aversive motivation in learning, behaviour and psychopathology; Pavlovian conditioning; instrumental conditioning; how goals are represented and how they drive behaviour; and the development of habitual and compulsive behaviours.  


Please note: Neuroscience major (NEURS1) students are exempt from the prerequisite of PSYC2001 Research Methods 2 as long as they have completed NEUR2201 Neuroscience Fundamentals. Note, however, that this condition does not apply to any students who are undertaking a Psychology major (PSYCA1 or PSYCB1) in addition to a Neuroscience major.

 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"00cc0aa3dbf59850eb6b147a3a9619f6","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Brief description of future experiments","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

A published journal article will be presented that describes an experiment in behavioural neuroscience of the sort that might form the basis for your research proposal and poster presentation (see below). The tutor will take you through the different aspects of the article (Abstract, Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion) and will highlight important features of the article in terms of the background and rationale for the study, the experimental methods and design employed, the presentation and analysis of results, and the conclusions that might be drawn from the study and how these might be integrated with existing published work and theory. Your task will be to write a brief description of an aspect of the article’s findings that you found interesting, and how one might follow-up on this finding with a further study (400 word maximum, marks strictly deducted for exceeding this limit: 3% [of 10% available] for anything between 400 and 500 words, and a further 3% [of the remaining 7% available] for 500-600 words, and all marks [10% of 10%] for >600 words – brevity is the key to the exercise). Any descriptions submitted 10 days after the due date will not be marked and will receive an automatic grade of 0.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"04cc0aa3dbf59850eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3bbc0aa3dbf59850eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"77bc0aa3dbf59850eb6b147a3a9619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bfbc0aa3dbf59850eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f7bc0aa3dbf59850eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fbbc0aa3dbf59850eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"67bc0aa3dbf59850eb6b147a3a9619ac","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research proposal presentation and poster","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"45","description":"

You are expected to conceive, design, and propose a research project in Behavioural Neuroscience. The specific research area and research question is determined by you. However, it is expected to be based upon the current literature. You will be expected to systematically review the relevant literature, identify an outstanding question of interest, and design an experiment that will address this question. This project will be assessed in two parts. The first part comprises oral presentations of your research proposal in Week 4 during tutorials. In the first presentation (3 minutes maximum) you will very briefly review your proposed topic area and identify a research question.  Your tutor will provide you with feedback in the time available – if your presentation takes the full time allotted, then there will be little feedback, so plan your presentation carefully. Based on this feedback, you will prepare a second presentation, which covers in more detail your research question, a proposed experiment, and some potential findings and possible interpretations and implications. You will have have 7 minutes for this presentation. These oral presentations will be made in Week 7 and will form the basis of your final poster submission. Completion of the oral presentations is a condition of completing the entire assessment. In week 9 you will also have the opportunity to present your poster to other students within the tutorial (in small groups) in order to allow you to both receive and give peer feedback prior to completion of your final poster for submission. The oral presentations count for 15% of your overall mark. The first presentation in week 4 is simply to get the ball rolling, and so completion of this presentation will result in a score of 5% towards your final mark provided you present an original idea to the tutorial group (i.e. it is pass/fail with a fixed award of 5%). The presentations in week 7 will be worth 10% of your final mark, based on quality. Electronic copies of your final poster must be submitted at the end of week 10 following the standard procedure. These electronic submissions will be checked by Turnitin. This poster accounts for 30% of your final mark for the course. This poster will be based on the presentations given in class, allowing you to incorporate feedback from your presentations (and those of others) into your final completed work. Any posters submitted 10 days after the week 10 due date will not be marked and will receive an automatic grade of 0.

The final examination will be held in the usual end of session examination period, and will assess both the lecture material and learning from the four practical classes and associated readings. This will take the format of an 75-question multiple choice examination over 2 hours, with 15 questions from each of the 4 sections of the course delivered by different lecturers (lecture content and associated readings), and 15 questions derived from practical classes in weeks 5, 6, 9 and associated readings.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PSYC3121","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC3121 - Social Psychology","description":"

This course provides a review of the history, principles, methods, and ethics of social psychology at an advanced level. Substantive research areas such as the nature of attraction, stereotypes and prejudice, aggression, morality and prosocial behaviour, among others, will be covered.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2604ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619cc","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

This combined participation mark comprises attendance at face-to-face tutorials (8%, 1% each), completion of online tutorial activities (3%, 1% each), and completion of the self-test quizzes* (4%, 1% each).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1204ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"1a04ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5a04ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619a1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9604ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619a4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4a04ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a961971","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Think tank group presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

This group presentation (15 mins) will be a culmination of group-based work (based on the Think Tank activities) in tutorials across the course. Additional information will be provided in an Assignment Sheet distributed in tutorials and posted to Moodle. Marks will incorporate peer evaluations from fellow group members (to be completed during Week 10).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1204ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"1a04ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5a04ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619a1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"5e04ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9604ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619a4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d204ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8204ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a961976","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Think tank write-up","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

This written assessment will involve a summary (1500 words) of your group’s Think Tank experiment idea, including a brief introduction/rationale and methodology, as well as a section engaging in critical thinking principles practiced throughout the course. Additional information will be provided in an Assignment Sheet distributed in tutorials and posted to Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1204ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"1a04ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5a04ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619a1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"5e04ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9604ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619a4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d204ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ca04ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a96197a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The 2 hour final exam will test your factual knowledge of and critical reasoning skills related to lecture material, readings, and tutorial content. Question formats will include fill-in-the-blank and short essay questions. The number of questions per topic will be proportional to the number of lectures and tutorials on the topic.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"1a04ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5a04ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619a1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"5e04ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9604ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619a4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d204ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ca04ae27dbf99850eb6b147a3a96198b","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PSYC3121.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: This course provides a review of the history, principles, methods, and ethics of social psychology at an advanced level. Substantive research areas such as the nature of attraction, stereotypes and prejudice, aggression, morality and prosocial behaviour, among others, will be covered.
contentlets.title: Social Psychology

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PSYC3202","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC3202 - Clinical and Cognitive Neuroscience","description":"

This course will provide an advanced coverage of major systems of the brain and how they are involved in both normal and abnormal functioning.  The course will also cover theoretical models of the aetiology and neural mechanisms of clinical pathologies (such as anxiety, depression, addiction, psychosis and aggression) and cognition, and the research evidence supporting them.  Research methods in Clinical and Cognitive Neuroscience, including experimental, analogue, genetic, imaging, longitudinal and epidemiological studies will be covered to outline the strengths and limitations of these techniques.  The course will consider both normal and abnormal functioning from the perspective of neuroscience, and will therefore also expand and deepen your understanding of human experimental psychology and its neural basis, including behaviour, cognition, emotion and development.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c56715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96196e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial preparation and participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Attendance and active participation in tutorials is an important component of the course.  Students will be expected to study the set readings before each tutorial and complete a brief quiz on Moodle that relates to each reading.  Each quiz that is completed prior to the tutorial is worth 1% (total 5%).  Students must also contribute to discussion of issues related to the reading, so each student will provide one discussion point for each reading during the term and lead the class discussion on that point (0-2% per reading for a total of 0-10%).  Performance on the discussion will be judged on the quality of the point raised and the ability of the student to lead the class debate.

In Week 6, a mid-term test consisting of short answer and/or multiple choice questions will be given in the lecture theatre.  The test will cover material related to lectures and tutorial readings from weeks 1-5.  Marks will be provided online via Moodle within 10 working days of the test.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"056715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"416715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7c6715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"8d6715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b86715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c56715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96195f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"c96715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96196a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6c6715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96193a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will submit via Turnitin a 2000-word APA research proposal in the style of a grant application that is due in week 10.  The proposal is worth 25% of the overall mark in the course.  Further information on the format and approach for the research proposal will be provided to students closer to the release date of the assessment.  Feedback will be provided online via Moodle 10 working days from the due date.  Any assessments submitted after feedback is returned to students will not be marked and will receive a grade of 0.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"056715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"416715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7c6715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961959","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"8d6715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b86715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c56715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96195f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"c96715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96196a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a46715bfdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96193f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The 2-hour final exam consisting of short answer and/or multiple choice questions will be scheduled during the official examination period and will cover material covered in both lectures and tutorials from weeks 1 through 10.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PSYC3211","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC3211 - Cognitive Science","description":"

This course will provide you with an advanced-level understanding of the current theories, methods and controversies in four key areas of cognitive psychology: 1) Judgment and Decision-making; 2) Theory and Models; 3) Categorisation and Reasoning; and (4) Intelligence and Thinking. The Judgment and Decision-making strand asks and answers questions like: Do we make rational decisions? Are we constrained to fall prey to systematic biases when we make judgments? Are we risk averse and if so what does that mean? It will also cover the burgeoning field of “behavioural insights” and the tools to ‘nudge’ people to change their behaviour. The Theory and Models strand focuses on the development and testing of computational models of cognitive processes, with an emphasis on models of working memory and long-term memory. The component is focused on how quantitative instantiations of models are necessary to provide a rigorous test of psychological theories. The Categorisation and Reasoning strand examines how and why people organise things in their physical and social environment into groups (e.g., dogs vs. cats, male vs. female, left-wing politician vs. right-wing politician?), and how they use such knowledge to reason and make predictions. The Intelligence and Thinking strand will address questions like: What is intelligence? Do IQ tests really measure intelligence (and if not, what DO they measure)? How do people use their past experience to solve new problems?


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"65366d37dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Experimental research report and presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The written assignment will begin in the tutorial in Week 3 and will be due by midnight on Thursday Week 10. In this assignment you will work in groups to design and conduct an experiment, and analyze the data. You will write up an INDIVIDUAL lab report (1750 words) communicating the results and give an oral presentation in groups. The presentation is worth 5% and the report is worth 35% of the total mark.

Feedback will be provided within 10 working days of the due date and will be available online via Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2d366d37dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"69366d37dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e9366d37dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ed366d37dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"11366d37dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961967","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-session exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

A mid-session exam in Week 4 will be worth 15% of the total mark. The exam will be conducted in tutorial/laboratory classes. This will assess the course content from the lectures on the first topic taught in the course (Judgment and Decision Making). It will comprise Multiple Choice Questions and short answer essay questions.  Feedback will be provided within 10 working days of the due date.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"69366d37dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9d366d37dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e9366d37dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ed366d37dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c5366d37dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961962","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

The final exam will be worth 45% of the total mark – it will assess content from topics not assessed by the Mid-session exam. It will comprise Multiple Choice Questions and short answer essay questions. There will be a choice of 2 short answer essay questions for each lecture topic (Categorisation and Reasoning; Theory and Models; Intelligence and Thinking), and you will be required to answer one question for each topic.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"69366d37dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9d366d37dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e9366d37dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ed366d37dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d5366d37dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961984","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PSYC3211.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PSYC3221","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC3221 - Vision and Brain","description":"

“Attempts to construct computer models for the recognition and interpretation of arbitrary scenes have resulted in such poor performance, limited range of abilities and inflexibility that, were it not for the human existence proof, we may have been tempted long ago to conclude that high performance, general purpose vision is impossible.” (Barrow & Tannenbaum, 1971).


Although written over 40 years ago, the above statement is still pertinent and relevant today: while seemingly effortless, human visual perception is a complex achievement taking up 40% of the entire cortex. In this course, the problem of visual processing will be considered from ecological, physiological, philosophical, and computational perspectives. The general orientation of the course is a theoretical one but applied aspects such as the role of basic perceptual processes in disorders such as autism and schizophrenia, and the implications for the design of effective visual displays will be discussed as well.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2ad866a3db3d9850eb6b147a3a96190b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Novel research project individual research report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

As part of this course you will be required to design and conduct a small-scale empirical research project in the area of visual perception. Written research reports (individual mark worth 25%) on this project are expected to be individually written and submitted via Turnitin. The report should be formatted as a research report for the journal Psychological Science and should be approximately 2000 words in length. The teaching staff will be available to advise you during all stages of your project.  Detailed instructions for this assignment will be released closer to the assessment due date. Marks and feedback will be returned to students within 10 working days of the due date and no submissions will be accepted after this date – any report submitted after then will not be marked and will receive a grade of 0.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"16d826a3db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2ad826a3db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"62d826a3db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"66d826a3db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"aed826a3db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ead826a3db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"16d826a3db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619df","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam will contain approximately 6 short essay questions: each lecturer will each write approximately 5 questions out of which you will choose 3 questions.  The exam will be based on the content covered in the lectures (Weeks 5-10, inclusive). No student should organise travel during this period until the final examination schedule has been released and the date of the exam is known. Further details regarding the exact time and location of the exam will be released on myUNSW as they become available.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"16d826a3db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"66d826a3db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"aed826a3db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5ed826a3db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619e3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-session exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Mid-session exam will consist of 30 multiple-choice questions and two short essay questions. The exam will be based on Weeks 1-4 material covered in lectures and tutorials. Practice questions will be provided in weeks leading up to the exam.  Marked exams scripts will be returned to students once marks are released (i.e. within 10 working days of the due date).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"16d826a3db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"66d826a3db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"aed826a3db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cad826a3db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619c9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Novel research project group presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

As part of this course you will be required to design and conduct a small-scale empirical research project in the area of visual perception. After the completion of your project, you will be asked to make a poster summary of your research projects with a short oral presentation (10 minutes) on your project (worth 15%). All members of the research group are required to take part in these presentations, as you will be awarded a single mark for the poster and its presentation as a group. Marks and feedback will be returned to students within 10 working days of the due date and no submissions will be accepted after this date – any assessment submitted after then will not be marked and will receive a grade of 0.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PSYC3241","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC3241 - Psychobiology of Memory","description":"

This course examines research and theory on memory. The focus is primarily on animal research but the application of this work to the understanding of memory in humans will be made explicit. For example, the implications of this work for our understanding of memory disorders in humans, and the origin and treatment of clinical disorders will be discussed.  The laboratory component of the course will provide “hands on” experience in observing various aspects of rodent behaviour that are frequently used in studies on the psychobiology of memory and an opportunity for small group discussion/debate on various issues relevant to the material described in the lecture component of the course

This 45-min exam (consisting largely of multiple choice questions with the possibility of some short-response questions) will be given during Week 5 in the regularly-scheduled lecture time period.  In cases where short-response questions will be included in an exam, this will be announced prior to the exam.  This exam will be based on lecture material covered in lectures from Week 1 to Week 3, and the readings for those lectures.

Feedback will be provided within 10 days of the due date and made available online via Moodle. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"408b69b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961912","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7f7b69b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bb7b69b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f77b69b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96190c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"177b29b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This involves a 1000-1250 word written research proposal on a proposed experiment (based on material/ideas covered in the course). An electronic version of the assignment must be submitted to the course’s Moodle page by 4 PM on Friday of Week 10 to allow for plagiarism checks via Turnitin. Penalties will be imposed for late submission of this assignment and for plagiarism. The deadline for absolute fail (i.e., the date of submission after which the task will not be assessed is 10 working days from the due date.

Feedback will be provided within 10 working days of the due date and will be provided online via Moodle.
