","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PSYC5005","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC5005 - Behavioural Neuroscience","description":"

This course examines the elementary processes of learning and memory and the neurobiological mechanism that underpin them. These include: learning about relations between events (Pavlovian conditioning), learning about relations between one’s behaviour and events (Instrumental conditioning), and how these forms of learning control behaviours. There will be an emphasis on the current experimental and theoretical research, including the role of neural systems in supporting behaviour, the role of molecular signalling cascades and neuronal encoding in learning and memory.  

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"68304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619e5","name":"Fully online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be required to write a research proposal (1500 words) for an experiment based on any of the areas of research presented in the course. Students will present their initial ideas in the Week 2 tutorial to receive formative feedback from peers and the tutor. The proposal will contain a literature review of the current research, a critique of the present research and a rationale for the proposed experiment. The final section will require students to propose one experiment, including relevant methodological information and expected results. The proposed experiment must logically follow from the literature review and contain a novel contribution to the research area.  The proposal is due Sunday Week 4.  Feedback will be provided online via Moodle on Monday Week 6 (any assessment submitted after this time will not be marked and recieve a mark of zero).

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1c304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"20304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619df","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"68304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6c304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a4304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e0304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1c304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly Secured Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be required to complete 5 quizzes under official exam conditions.  These quizzes will cover the content of the lectures and readings. The quizzes will be held in weeks 2-6 and will cover content presented in the previous week. The “Secured” quizzes form part of a continuous assessment (8% per secured quiz). Each Quiz will include 30 multiple choice questions.  The due date for each quiz is Sunday 11.59 pm the week each quiz is released (i.e. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).  Feedback is provided online via Gradebook on the Monday following quiz submission.

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1c304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"68304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6c304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a4304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e0304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"54304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Clinical applications oral presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students can choose any area of research discussed in the course to discuss the clinical applications of this research. Students should identify one type of animal research and discuss the basic theories which explain the phenomena. They then need to provide an example of how this research has been translated to clinical applications. This will allow students to explore the applied context of animal research in the wider and clinical community. Students will need to upload a 10-minute video to Moodle in order to present their findings to the class.  This assessment is due Monday Week 6.  Feedback will be provided online via Moodle on Friday Week 6 (any assessment submitted after this time will not be marked and recieve a mark of zero).

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1c304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"20304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619df","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"68304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6c304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a4304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e0304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9c304973db391c50eb6b147a3a9619bd","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PSYC5005.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This course will address topics relating to the development and interaction of biological, cognitive, emotional and social processes across the lifespan. These topics will be investigated in different stages of life including prenatal and early development, childhood, adolescence, late adulthood and senescence. The course will also address the aetiology of psychological disorders related to these life stages such as developmental disorders and dementias.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"94aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619cf","name":"Fully online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Group work","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be allocated into groups and assigned one area of development across the lifespan. They will be required to research and discuss the current research regarding one issue in this area. The group will need to provide a summary of the research (750 words) in order to share the information with the rest of the cohort. This will allow students to develop an understanding of developmental psychology in a broader sense.  This assessment is due Sunday Week 2. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d0aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d0aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d8aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"d8aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d8aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dcaff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"28aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619e7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be required to choose one area of development across the lifespan to research and discuss. Students will have the opportunity to pick a topic which is of particular interest to them. The assessment will require students to submit a 1500 word essay (individually) discussing their chosen issue in lifespan development. They will be required to complete a critical analysis of the issues related to this stage of development based on the current research.  The essay is due Sunday of Week 4.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d0aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d0aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d8aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"d8aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d8aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dcaff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2caff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619df","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will be required to provide feedback on assessment the group work assessment for two students from a different group. Once they have returned their feedback, they should provide a self-reflection (500 words) on the feedback provided by their peer-reviewers. This allows students to develop the skills of providing constructive feedback in a sensitive manner. Further, students will learn about the peer review process and develop skills for self-reflection and integrating feedback.  This assessment is due Sunday Week 3.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d0aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d0aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d8aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"d8aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d8aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dcaff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"98aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Weekly Secured Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be required to complete 5 quizzes under official exam conditions.  These quizzes will cover the content of the lectures and readings. The quizzes will be held in weeks 2-6 and will cover content presented in the previous week. The “Secured” quizzes form part of a continuous assessment (8% per secured quiz). Each Quiz will include 30 multiple choice questions.  The due date for each quiz is Sunday 11.59 pm the week each quiz is released (i.e. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).  Feedback is provided online via Gradebook on the Monday following quiz submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d0aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d0aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d8aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"d8aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dcaff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619d0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f8aff6a7db45b450fe4b322af49619fb","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PSYC5006.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PSYC5007","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC5007 - The Individual, Culture and Society","description":"

This course will provide an advanced overview of topics relating to self-identity, culture and sociality. Topics will include the formation of identity, cross-cultural psychology, indigenous psychology, biological mechanisms underpinning social learning and attribution, as well as social disorders. The course will cover the principles and methodology of research into social phenomena such as affiliation, attraction, group behaviour and prejudice.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"77408d73db391c50eb6b147a3a961989","name":"Fully online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly Secured Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be required to complete 5 quizzes under official exam conditions.  These quizzes will cover the content of the lectures and readings. The quizzes will be held in weeks 2-6 and will cover content presented in the previous week. The “Secured” quizzes form part of a continuous assessment (8% per secured quiz). Each Quiz will include 30 multiple choice questions.  The due date for each quiz is Sunday 11.59 pm the week each quiz is released (i.e. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).  Feedback is provided online via Gradebook on the Monday following quiz submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2b408d73db391c50eb6b147a3a961977","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"67408d73db391c50eb6b147a3a96197a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6b408d73db391c50eb6b147a3a961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a3408d73db391c50eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ef408d73db391c50eb6b147a3a96197f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1f408d73db391c50eb6b147a3a961937","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Reflection Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be required to complete a critical reflection (1500 words) on three pieces of psychological research presented in the media. Students may choose any articles from popular media outlets or “popular-psychology” magazines that relate to personality, social and cultural psychology. This will require students to answer a series of questions related to the validity of the media reports, find the original research article and reflect on the difference in the presentation of the findings between popular psychology and peer review journal publications.  This assessment is due Sunday Week 3.  Feedback will be provided online via Moodle on Sunday Week 5 (assessments submitted after this date will not be marked and recieve a mark of zero).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2b408d73db391c50eb6b147a3a961977","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2f408d73db391c50eb6b147a3a961982","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"67408d73db391c50eb6b147a3a96197a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6b408d73db391c50eb6b147a3a961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a3408d73db391c50eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ef408d73db391c50eb6b147a3a96197f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"57408d73db391c50eb6b147a3a96193c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be required to pick an issue related to a minority group in Australian society OR an issue related to cultural psychology and indigenous issues. Students will be required to identify one issue of interest in this area, complete a literature review and evaluate the possible psychological explanations for this issue (1500 words). Students will be required to complete a critical analysis of the existing literature and current strategies in place for dealing with their chosen issue.  This assessment is due Monday Week 5.  Feedback will be provided online via Moodle on Sunday Week 6 (assessments submitted after this date will not be marked and recieve a mark of zero).

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PSYC5008","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC5008 - Perception and Cognition","description":"

This course introduces students to those areas of psychology that are more closely concerned with “the mind”. The fundamental principles underlying human perception and cognition introduced in the course are perceptual organisation, perception of spatial layout, perceptual learning, object recognition, attention, memory storage and retrieval, problem solving and decision making.  The practical program will provide an introduction to the use of psychophysical methods, experimental approaches to the study of cognitive processes, and the application of findings in society.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e450cd73db391c50eb6b147a3a96190d","name":"Fully online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly Secured Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be required to complete 5 quizzes under official exam conditions.  These quizzes will cover the content of the lectures and readings. The quizzes will be held in weeks 2-6 and will cover content presented in the previous week. The “Secured” quizzes form part of a continuous assessment (8% per secured quiz). Each Quiz will include 30 multiple choice questions.  The due date for each quiz is Sunday 11.59 pm the week each quiz is released (i.e. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).  Feedback is provided online via Gradebook on the Monday following quiz submission. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"10508d73db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1c508d73db391c50eb6b147a3a9619e2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"24508d73db391c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5c508d73db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"98508d73db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0c508d73db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be required to complete a literature review (1000 words) on an assigned topic. This will be directly linked with the experimental data provided in assessment 2. This will provide students with the opportunity to submit a draft introduction for the research report and receive feedback prior to submission of the research report assessment.  The literature review is due Sunday Week 2.  Feedback will be provided online via Moodle Monday Week 4 (any assessment submitted after this date will not be marked and recieve a mark of zero).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"10508d73db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1c508d73db391c50eb6b147a3a9619e2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"24508d73db391c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5c508d73db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"98508d73db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d4508d73db391c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"44508d73db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be required to participate in an online experiment designed to elicit data for this assessment and to analyse the data obtained from all students. In the report (2000 words) they will have to describe the experimental procedure and data analysis method, to present the results of their analysis and to interpret the results within an appropriate theoretical framework and in the light of previous research. The research report is due Sunday Week 4.  Feedback will be provided online via Moodle Sunday Week 6 (any assessment submitted after this date will not be marked and recieve a mark of zero).

This course will provide a contemporary view of issues associated with human mental health and psychopathology. It will introduce and discuss the notion of abnormality in behaviour, how a range of mental disorders are diagnosed, the prognosis and treatment in human mental disorders as well as the stigma and media coverage of mental health.

The quizzes will be held in weeks 2-6 and will cover content presented in the previous week. The “Secured” quizzes form part of a continuous assessment (8% per secured quiz). Each Quiz will include 30 multiple choice questions and will cover content presented in the previous week.  The due date for each quiz is Sunday 11.59 pm the week each quiz is released (i.e. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).  Feedback is provided online via Gradebook on the Monday following quiz submission. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1950cd73db391c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5550cd73db391c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8d50cd73db391c50eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c950cd73db391c50eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"dd50cd73db391c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bc50cd73db391c50eb6b147a3a961947","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be required to pick two similar disorders from those covered in the course. They will need to perform a literature review (2000 words) in order to discuss how the diagnostic criteria, etiology and treatment of these disorders are connected. This will require students to be able to evaluate the link between mental health disorders which share similar criteria. Students will be required to reflect on the difficulty of the diagnostic model with a focus on the overlap and similarities of their chosen mental health disorders.  This assessment is due Monday Week 5.  Feedback will be provided online via Moodle Sunday Week 6 (no assessments submitted after this date will be marked and will recieve a mark of zero).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1950cd73db391c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5550cd73db391c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8d50cd73db391c50eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9150cd73db391c50eb6b147a3a961972","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c950cd73db391c50eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"dd50cd73db391c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bc50cd73db391c50eb6b147a3a961958","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Oral presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be assigned one mental health disorder covered in the course. They will need to research the diagnostic criteria, etiology and treatment of this disorder. Students will then produce a 15-20 minute oral presentation to communicate their findings to the class. Students will upload their presentation as a video file.  This assessment is due Monday Week 3.  Feedback will be provided online via Moodle Sunday Week 4 (no assessments submitted after this date will be marked and will recieve a mark of zero).

contentlets.keywords: psychology,online psychology course,psychology courses,psychology degree,online psychology degree,graduate diploma in psychology
contentlets.description: This course will provide a contemporary view of issues associated with human mental health and psychopathology. It will introduce and discuss the notion of abnormality in behaviour, how a range of mental disorders are diagnosed, the prognosis and treatment in human mental disorders as well as the stigma and media coverage of mental health.
contentlets.title: Abnormal Psychology

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PSYC5010","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC5010 - Psychological Assessment, Ethics, and Professional Skills","description":"

Psychological assessment and testing are a critical component in the practice and research of psychology. This course will provide an overview of the design and implementation for a range of psychological assessments and tools. The course will allow students to critically evaluate the use of assessment tools in psychological research and practice. The course will further explore the importance of ethics in research and clinical practice. Students will have the opportunity to develop basic professional skills required for further study and practice in the field of psychology.

Students will be required to complete 5 quizzes under official exam conditions.  These quizzes will cover the content of the lectures and readings. The quizzes will be held in weeks 2-6 and will cover content presented in the previous week. The “Secured” quizzes form part of a continuous assessment (8% per secured quiz). Each Quiz will include 30 multiple choice questions and will.  The due date for each quiz is Sunday 11.59 pm the week each quiz is released (i.e. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).  Feedback is provided online via Gradebook on the Monday following quiz submission. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"71e67884dba75410eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"71e67884dba75410eb6b147a3a961934","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"71e67884dba75410eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"79e67884dba75410eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"79e67884dba75410eb6b147a3a961934","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"86e6b884dba75410eb6b147a3a961982","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Ethics Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be required to discuss three ethical dilemmas (1500 words). They will need to identify if there is an ethical concern in each scenario and identify what this concern is based on the evidence from the appropriate ethics code to justify their answer. They will then need to provide a potential solution for each dilemma based on the ethics code and guidelines. This assessment will provide students with the opportunity to familiarise themselves with the ethics guidelines.  This assessment is due Sunday Week 5.  Feedback will be provided online via Moodle Sunday Week 6 (any portfolio submitted after this date will not be marked and will recieve a mark of zero).  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"71e67884dba75410eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"71e67884dba75410eb6b147a3a961934","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"71e67884dba75410eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"79e67884dba75410eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"79e67884dba75410eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"79e67884dba75410eb6b147a3a961934","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bde6b884dba75410eb6b147a3a961979","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Evaluation Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be required to critically evaluate a psychological assessment of their choice from any area of applied psychology. They will be required to complete an essay (2000 words) that focuses on the appropriateness of assessment in psychology and the issues relating to the reliability and validity of this measure. This will involve students reviewing current literature in order to discuss the critical issues in psychological assessment. Students will need to apply critical thinking skills in order to review and evaluate this approach.  This essay is due Sunday Week 3.  Feedback will be provided online via Moodle Sunday Week 5 (any essays submitted after this date will not be marked and will recieve a mark of zero).

contentlets.keywords: psychology,online psychology course,psychology courses,psychology degree,online psychology degree,graduate diploma in psychology
contentlets.description: Psychological assessment and testing are a critical component in the practice and research of psychology. This course will provide an overview of the design and implementation for a range of psychological assessments and tools. The course will allow students to critically evaluate the use of assessment tools in psychological research and practice. The course will further explore the importance of ethics in research and clinical practice. Students will have the opportunity to develop basic professional skills required for further study and practice in the field of psychology.
contentlets.title: Psychological Assessment, Ethics, and Professional Skills

This course aims to engage you with current theories and key concepts underpinning executive intelligence to support your development of critical thinking and executive decision making. You will learn about four key areas of executive intelligence namely: 1) intelligence and thinking; 2) judgment, decision-making and reasoning; 3) biological mechanisms underpinning social learning and attribution and 4) the principles underpinning social and emotional phenomena such as affiliation, attraction, group behaviour prejudice, stereotypes, aggression, morality and prosocial behaviour. You will be able to again a broad understanding of the core principles of how cognitive and social processes can improve reasoning, informed decision making and memorisation and information processing within the context of your professional practice.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"96ef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96198c","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Think Tank activities and presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment task is assessed as Group work. Students will be required to work in a group to complete Think Tank activities in the tutorials then draw all the Think Tank activities together in a 15 minute group presentation. They will use Collaborate ultra to conduct the presentation. Presentation will be recorded and submitted to Moodle for assessment. 

\n

Additional information will be provided in an Assignment Sheet distributed in tutorials and posted to Moodle. Marks will incorporate peer evaluations of other group members’ contribution to group work (to be completed during Week 10).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"16ef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"52ef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961954","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9aef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d6ef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"02ef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961923","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Think Tank write up","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment task is assessed as Individuals. You will be required to write a report (1500 words) on your group’s Think Tank experiment idea. In the report, you should include a brief introduction of the idea, rationale, methodology of the experiment, any results up to this point and a discussion of the results/findings. You will also be required to demonstrate throughout the report how you have applied the principles of critical thinking to accomplish the Think Tank activities and/or the experiment idea.

\n

Additional information will be provided in an Assignment Sheet distributed in tutorials and posted to Moodle. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"16ef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"52ef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961954","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9aef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d6ef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"02ef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961934","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

The 1 hour final exam (online) will test your factual knowledge of and critical reasoning skills related to lecture material, readings, and tutorial content. Question formats will include fill-in-the-blank and short essay questions. The number of questions per topic will be proportional to the number of lectures and tutorials on the topic

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"16ef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"52ef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961954","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9aef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961988","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4aef49bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961938","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be required to complete 5 quizzes. These quizzes will be held weekly during weeks 2-6 and will cover content presented in the lectures and readings in the previous week. Each quiz will include 30 multiple choice questions. The due date for each quiz is Sunday 11.59 pm the week each quiz is released (i.e. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).  Feedback is provided online via Gradebook on the Monday following quiz submission.

This course focuses on understanding how psychology and cognitive science underpin the creative practices and introduce them to processes and methods that lead to innovation. You will learn key concepts of human centred design, blended with principles of psychology and cognitive science. You will learn to identify conditions required for the emergence of ideas, inspiration and change through examining historical cases of innovation. You will engage with a range of transdisciplinary frameworks and methods for entrepreneurial innovation, creative thinking, ideation and prototyping to develop a new solution to an identified problem. You will be able to gain an advanced understanding of cognitive science, motivational theories, behavioural economics, neural processes and social influences and use this body of knowledge to dive deeper into the innovation frameworks used by industry to create new products, services and technology. The course aims to foster values such as risk-taking and inquisitiveness in research, develop high level analytical and creative practices, and encourage an explorative attitude towards the design and innovation process.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"39656db3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619bf","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Periodic quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Online multiple-choice quizzes (20% of final mark in total; due Sunday week 3, Sunday week 5, Sunday week 10)
Each quiz will consist of 20 multiple-choice questions which you must answer in 15 minutes (approximately 45 seconds should be spent on each question). 

Quiz 1: Due Sunday week 3, covers weeks 2 and 3 psychology lecture content
Quiz 2: Due Sunday week 5, covers weeks 4 and 5 psychology lecture content
Quiz 3: Due Sunday week 10, covers weeks 9 and 10 psychology lecture content

In accordance with UNSW Assessment Policy the quizzes will be completed online and require a stable internet connection. Quizzes may not be attempted twice, and must be attempted during the window it is open. Feedback for each quiz will be released once a) the submission window has closed, and b) all students have taken the quiz.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a9656db3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f5656db3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96199a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"99656db3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961978","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Workbook Part A","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

You are required to complete a project in 2 parts: Part A and Part B. In Part A you will submit process work based on material from weeks 1-4, guided by a provided framework and activities.  Part A is due in Week 6.

Part A will require you to 1) identify a problem area/hypothesis; 2) design a research plan; 3) conduct semi-structured interviews; 4) synthesise insights from collected data; & 5) reflect on the process.

In accordance with UNSW Assessment Policy the assignment must be submitted online via Turnitin. No paper or emailed copies will be accepted. Assessments will receive a deduction for every day late. Marks and feedback will be returned via Moodle within 10 working days of the due date.  Any assignment submitted after feedback is returned will receive a 0 unless pior exemption has been granted.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"71656db3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a9656db3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"bd656db3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f5656db3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96199a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e1656db3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96197d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Workbook Part B","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

Part B requires you to continue from where you left off at the end of Part A, and will include human centred design and research activities based on material from weeks 5-9.  Part B is due in Week 11.

Part B will require you to 1) adjust your strategy in response to feedback from Part A; 2) undertake and capture your design and ideation process; 3) collate insights from user testing; 4) suggest iterations and next steps; & 5) reflect on your innovation journey

In accordance with UNSW Assessment Policy the assignment must be submitted online via Turnitin. No paper or emailed copies will be accepted. Assessments will receive a deduction for every day late. Marks and feedback will be returned via Moodle within 10 working days of the due date.  Any assignment submitted after feedback is returned will receive a 0 unless pior exemption has been granted.

contentlets.keywords: psychology,human centred design,organisational psychology,cognitive science,creative practices,entrepreneurial innovation,innovation process and methods
contentlets.description: This course focuses on understanding how psychology and cognitive science underpin the creative practices and introduce them to processes and methods that lead to innovation. You will learn key concepts of human centred design, blended with principles of psychology and cognitive science. You will learn to identify conditions required for the emergence of ideas, inspiration and change through examining historical cases of innovation. You will engage with a range of transdisciplinary frameworks and methods for entrepreneurial innovation, creative thinking, ideation and prototyping to develop a new solution to an identified problem. You will be able to gain an advanced understanding of cognitive science, motivational theories, behavioural economics, neural processes and social influences and use this body of knowledge to dive deeper into the innovation frameworks used by industry to create new products, services and technology. The course aims to foster values such as risk-taking and inquisitiveness in research, develop high level analytical and creative practices, and encourage an explorative attitude towards the design and innovation process.
contentlets.title: The Psychology of Human-Centred Design and Innovation

The overall aim of this course is to provide students with a basic understanding of elementary neural systems as they support processes related to learning, memory, cognition and emotion in the real world. Students will learn about contemporary theories and approaches to neuroscience, including the role of neuronal coding in learning and memory, and the role of different neural systems in supporting behaviour. Students will be able to gain an understanding of the neuroscience of cognitive and emotional function, and how these may play a role in human behaviour and performance in a range of settings.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b0ff89bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ee","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be required to complete 5 quizzes. These quizzes will be held weekly during weeks 2-6 and will cover content presented in the lectures and readings in the previous week. Each quiz will include 30 multiple choice questions. The due date for each quiz is Sunday 11.59 pm the week each quiz is released (i.e. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).  Feedback is provided online via Gradebook on the Monday following quiz submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"28ff89bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2cff89bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"50ff89bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619aa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Oral presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment task allows students to explore the application of neuroscience research in the wider workplace environment. They will be asked to choose an area of neuroscience covered in the course and discuss the application(s) of this area in a workplace in an oral presentation. In the presentation, students should introduce the neuroscience area, identify the underpinning theories that explain the phenomena, and discuss how this research has been translated to real-life application(s) in the workplace.

The presentation will be 10 minutes and video recorded. Students are required to upload the video and the material they have used in supporting their presentation, such as PP slides, to the Moodle site of the course for assessment. The video will account for 20% of the course grade and the supporting material will account for 20%.

This assessment is due Monday Week 10.  Feedback will be provided online via Moodle 10 working days from the due date Assessment submitted after this time will not be marked and will receive a mark of zero. Alternative assessment arrangement will be made for students with approved special consideration.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"28ff89bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2cff89bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"78ff89bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b4ff89bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ea","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"60ff89bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619cc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be required to select a topic of neuroscience covered in the course and write a critical review of how the research and findings relating to this topic was presented in the media compared to peer-reviewed journal articles.

They will be required to locate 3 articles from popular media outlets or magazines that presented research and findings relating to this topic of neuroscience. They will then be required to use a series of given questions to assess the validity of how neuroscience was presented in these 3 media articles. Students will also be required to locate the original research article(s) and reflect on the difference in the presentation of the research and findings between popular media and peer review journal publications. 

This assessment is due Sunday Week 8.  Feedback will be provided online via Moodle on Sunday Week 10.  Assessment submitted after this time will not be marked and will receive a mark of zero. Alternative assessment arrangement will be made for students with approved special consideration

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PSYC5111","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC5111 - Evaluating Evidence","description":"

This course provides students with knowledge about the characteristics of the scientific method in general, with a particular focus on experimental methodology, experimental design, and data analysis in the behavioural sciences. It provides a comprehensive foundation in critical thinking, enabling students to understand and critically evaluate published research, and discriminate between evidence-based information and pseudoscience. This includes a background in the design and execution of empirical studies, a basic understanding of statistics and its function in scientific research, the interpretation of experimental findings, and the ability to evaluate conclusions and extrapolate their implications in broader contexts. Students will explore different methodological approaches and data collection and analytic techniques via online lectures and discussion, as well as gaining practical experience in experimental design and the critical evaluation of research. This course is appropriate for students with and without a background in science and is taught entirely online through Moodle.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"165be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","name":"Fully online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Media Article Comparison","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be given examples of a research article and media piece (e.g. newspaper article) to critically evaluate. Through open-ended questions they will be asked to identify and describe a number of concepts presented in the research methods lectures, including: the research question and hypotheses, experimental design, independent and dependent variables, and confounding variables. Finally, they will be asked to compare and critically evaluate the conclusions drawn in media piece relative to the research article making specific reference to research methods concepts.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"025be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"1a5be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5e5be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9a5be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9e5be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"da5be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0a5be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96197f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will be required to complete 6 quizzes under official online exam conditions. These quizzes will cover the content of the lectures and readings. The quizzes will be held in weeks 1-6 and will cover content presented in the week they are released. The secured quizzes form part of a cumulative assessment; of the 6 quizzes completed, the best 5 scores will contribute towards the 50% total weighting (10% each quiz). Each quiz will comprise 20 multiple choice questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"025be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5e5be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9a5be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"395be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96196e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Study Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students work with tutors to define a research question based around a set of descriptive statistics. They will develop a research proposal for an experimental study to investigate their chosen research question. This will include an introduction to the study (in which they provide justification for the study design based on the existing descriptive data), an outline of the experimental design (aims, hypotheses, operationalised dependent and independent variables) and proposed method for data collection (procedure for group allocation, experimental manipulation, and measurement). Students will need to present and summarise the provided descriptive data as part of their justification.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PSYC5112","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC5112 - Introduction to Psychology","description":"

This course introduces the principles and methods of psychology as a basic science, with specific reference to fundamental topics that will prove relevant to the study of child development. Students will explore the social and biological bases of behaviour in introductory topics including: Human Development, Attention and Memory, Learning and Cognition, Personality and Social Psychology, Abnormal Psychology, and Health Psychology. In addition, students will be trained in the methods of psychological inquiry and the critical evaluation of research. This course is appropriate for students with and without a background in science and is taught entirely online through Moodle.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"535b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961917","name":"Fully online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Information Literacy Skills Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be required to complete a comprehensive literature search using a range of databases in order to find 3 peer-reviewed journal articles about one of the major topics presented in the course. Students will then answer a series of questions designed to demonstrate knowledge of appropriate academic references. Evidence of the database search, the articles, and the answers to the questions will be submitted in an e-portfolio. This assessment will provide students with the opportunity to demonstrate research and critical analysis skills.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0b5b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"435b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"475b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8f5b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cb5b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96190d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"365be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be required to complete a literature review based on the concepts presented in one of the modules. The literature review will provide students with the opportunity to develop skills in research and writing. There will be a focus on developing the skills for clear and concise communication, which is important for scientific writing. This assessment will allow students to develop discipline-specific communication skills.

This course will address topics relating to the development and interaction of biological, cognitive, emotional, and social processes across the stages of early life, including prenatal, infancy, childhood, and adolescence. Course content will review the research methodology, findings, and contemporary theories relating to the normal development of perception, cognition, social interaction, and emotion. Students will gain experience in the design and evaluation of empirical research in the area of developmental psychology, and the application of this research in broader societal contexts. This course is taught entirely online through Moodle.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"cf516d89dbc9f810fe4b322af4961992","name":"Fully online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Work","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be allocated into groups and assigned one area of developmental change in early life. They will be required to research and discuss the current evidence regarding one issue in this area. The group will need to provide a written summary of the research in order to share the information with the rest of the cohort, which should include a discussion of the strength of the evidence and the potential application of the findings in broader contexts. This will allow students to develop an understanding of developmental psychology in a broader sense. There can be no extensions allowed for this assessment – please be aware of the needs of your group members and work in a timely manner. Each student will complete an evaluation of the contribution of other group members, and the average score awarded by the group will contribute to students’ individual mark component of the assessment. Students will receive both a group and individual mark for this assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"875165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"875165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"875165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8b5165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"8f5165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8f5165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619f1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4f5165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619f3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reponse","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will be required to provide feedback on assessment 2 for one group in an area outside of their assigned area. Once they have returned their feedback, they should provide a written response on the feedback provided by their peer-reviewers. This allows students to develop the skills of providing constructive feedback in a sensitive manner. Further, students will learn about the peer review process and develop skills for self-reflection and integrating feedback. Students will receive marks for the quality of their feedback and completion of their response.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"875165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8b5165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8f5165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619f1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5f51a5c9dbc9f810fe4b322af4961954","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will be required to complete 6 quizzes under official online exam conditions. These quizzes will cover the content of the lectures and readings. The quizzes will be held in weeks 1-6 and will cover content presented in the week they are released. The secured quizzes form part of a cumulative assessment; of the 6 quizzes completed, the best 5 scores will contribute towards the 50% total weighting (10% each quiz). Each quiz will comprise 20 multiple choice questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"875165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"875165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8f5165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619f1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9b51a5c9dbc9f810fe4b322af4961905","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be required to choose one area of development across early life to research and discuss. Students will have the opportunity to pick a topic which is of particular interest to them. The assessment will require students to submit an essay (individually) discussing a particular issue in their chosen area of early-life development. They will be required to complete a critical analysis of the different factors relating to this issue based on the current research, as well as provide discussion of potential solutions and/or implications.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"875165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"875165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"875165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8b5165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"8f5165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8f5165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619f1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9f5165c9dbc9f810fe4b322af49619fd","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PSYC5113.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PSYC5114","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC5114 - Learning and Cognition","description":"

This course will address advanced-level topics relating to learning and cognition. These include models of associative learning, the biological and physiological basis of learning, decision-making (choice, control, and judgement), models of attention and memory, and thinking and reasoning. In addition, this course will discuss the ways in which theories and models of learning and cognition can be applied in child development and education. Course content will review the research methodology, findings, and contemporary theories relating to fundamental learning and cognitive processes. Students will gain experience in conducting empirical research, scientific writing, and the application of theoretical and empirical research to real-world situations. This course is taught entirely online through Moodle.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3c6b65b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961903","name":"Fully online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will be required to complete 6 quizzes under official online exam conditions. These quizzes will cover the content of the lectures and readings. The quizzes will be held in weeks 1-6 and will cover content presented in the week they are released. The secured quizzes form part of a cumulative assessment; of the 6 quizzes completed, the best 5 scores will contribute towards the 50% total weighting (10% each quiz). Each quiz will comprise 20 multiple choice questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"286b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"746b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b06b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619eb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"186b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Oral Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will be required to prepare an oral presentation that discusses the how any one of the psychological constructs presented in the course might relate to child learning and behaviour (e.g. in education, social contexts, health services, etc.). The presentation should include a critical evaluation of the current research and theory that would support such an application. Students will be required to upload a video presentation of no more than 10 minutes in length and will be graded on the content of the presentation, not the production values of the recording.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"286b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"306b65b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"746b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b06b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619eb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f06b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fc6b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"606b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Peer Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"5","description":"

Students will be required to provide a peer review of the oral presentation for two fellow students. They will be provided with a marking rubric and given instruction on how to provide constructive and meaningful feedback.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"306b65b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f06b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fc6b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"606b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Report Discussion","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be provided with a research proposal and some accompanying data. They will be required to interpret and write up the research findings as for the discussion section of a research article. This should include a summary of the results, critical comparison of the results to proposed hypotheses and past literature, conclusions, wider implications, and suggestions for future research.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"286b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"306b65b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"746b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b06b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619eb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f06b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fc6b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a86b25b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619cf","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PSYC5114.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PSYC5115","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC5115 - Developmental Psychopathology","description":"

This course will provide an in-depth examination of the most common developmental disorders affecting children and adolescents, including attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), conduct disorder (CD), oppositional defiance disorder (ODD) and eating disorders (ED), as well as autism and learning disabilities. Course content will address contemporary research findings and theories relating to the aetiology and treatment of these conditions, as well as discussion around what is and is not a disorder in the context of official diagnostic criteria and individual variation in developmental milestones and capabilities. Students will gain experience in the design and implementation of empirical research into developmental disorders, as well as the application of psychological tools and interventions in clinical settings. This course is taught entirely online through Moodle.

Students will be required to complete 6 quizzes under official online exam conditions. These quizzes will cover the content of the lectures and readings. The quizzes will be held in weeks 1-6 and will cover content presented in the week they are released. The secured quizzes form part of a cumulative assessment; of the 6 quizzes completed, the best 5 scores will contribute towards the 50% total weighting (10% each quiz). Each quiz will comprise 20 multiple choice questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"216b65b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6d6b65b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e16b65b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96195d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1d6b65b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961931","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Full Research Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be supplied with a research question and a dataset to accompany it. The task will be to produce a full research report in the style of an academic article, structured around this research question and dataset. It should include the following components: abstract, introduction, methods, results, discussion, and references.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"216b65b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"256b65b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6d6b65b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a96b65b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e16b65b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e56b65b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961968","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1d6b65b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961953","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thought Paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be given a range of scientific articles to choose from. The task will be to read the chosen article, provide a brief summary of the findings, and then relate these findings to a real-world scenario in which there are implications for policy or practice. The student should detail these implications, as well as make suggestions for follow-up research that could further investigate these and/or outline the potential application of the findings in a real-world setting.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PSYC5116","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC5116 - Wellbeing and Resilience","description":"

This course will address advanced-level topics relating to the development and maintenance of wellbeing and resilience in children and adolescents. These include self-esteem, self-efficacy, coping, risk-taking, and responsibility. Course content will involve a critical review of current research findings and contemporary theories pertaining to development within these topic areas, as well as a discussion of factors that can interact with and obstruct this development. Students will develop skills in the creation of novel research questions, translating empirical data to real-world contexts with practical applications, and disseminating scientific ideas in a variety of formats for different purposes.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"615be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961934","name":"Fully online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Translational Piece","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be required to undertake a literature search to choose a recent empirical finding related to one of the core topic areas in the course. The task will be to produce a written piece that summarises and presents these findings, and their practical implications, for a more general audience. Students will be able to choose the format for their written work. For example, it could be an opinion piece, newspaper article, policy recommendation, etc. In addition to submitting for marking, students will be required to post their written piece in the discussion forum on Moodle. As a requirement for completion, each student will need to read and comment on at least 3 other students’ submissions (100 words each).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"155be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"295be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"515be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961925","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"655be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9d5be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d95be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4d5be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961918","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will be required to complete 6 quizzes under official online exam conditions. These quizzes will cover the content of the lectures and readings. The quizzes will be held in weeks 1-6 and will cover content presented in the week they are released. The secured quizzes form part of a cumulative assessment; of the 6 quizzes completed, the best 5 scores will contribute towards the 50% total weighting (10% each quiz). Each quiz will comprise 20 multiple choice questions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"155be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"515be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961925","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9d5be1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"855ba1b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ea","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be able to choose from a selection of research papers relating to the various course topics. The task will be to derive a novel research question inspired by the chosen paper (and/or related articles) and construct a research proposal around this question. The research proposal is to include a literature review that highlights the gap in current knowledge that the research question aims to address, a clear description of aims and hypotheses, a full account of the proposed methodology, and an outline of expected results.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC7000 - Research Methods","description":"

This course involves an introduction to research methodologies that are central to the profession of clinical psychologist. Students will attend five workshops throughout the course, which cover topics including meta-analysis, threats to validity, randomized controlled trials, Bayesian approaches to statistics and the replication crisis.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"597be5b3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96198e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Workshop attendance","assessment_type":{"label":"Attendance","value":"attendance"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"100","description":"

Students will be required to attend all five workshops presented in this course to ensure they are consistently working towards achieving the professional graduate competencies for specialised areas of practice required by the APAC Accreditation Standards. These Accreditation Standards are incorporated in Program and Course Learning Outcomes.

contentlets.description: This course involves an introduction to research methodologies that are central to the profession of clinical psychologist. Students will attend five workshops throughout the course, which cover topics including meta-analysis, threats to validity, randomized controlled trials, Bayesian approaches to statistics and the replication crisis.
contentlets.title: Research Methods
