Continuation of training of psychological assessment and treatment skills and ethical practices required in the professional context. This course is associated with the placement requirement of the program (successful completion of second external placement).

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bb5ae9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96194e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Skill development: ethical case presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Completion of ethical problem solving task (provided in class 1) using ethical problem solving format (see slides from Psyc7409). Documentation required:

-        Paper of no more than 2000 words outlining ethical problem solving of ethical case (available on Moodle)

Verbal feedback will be provided by colleagues and Course Convenor following the presentation.  Marks and written feedback will be provided by the Course Convenor/Clinic Director to students within 10 working days of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"235aa9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"235ae9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6f5aa9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"7f5ae9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ab5aa9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"bb5ae9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e75ae9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"f75ae9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5b5aa9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Review meeting with Course Convenor and/or Supervisors of student professional skill development and performance with their clients.  Meeting documentation must include:

-      Agenda (with time marks embedded within Session Breakdown document, as well as other relevant queries about professional development placements, feedback on documentation, etc.). Agenda should be learning rather than outcome focussed.

-       risk assessment of client, including ONLY the following sections – introduction, presentation, limitations, risk formulation, treatment and supervision recommendations (you do not need to include the background information). Do not utilize UFPC report template.

-        Treatment Summary Report (do not use UFPC template).

Verbal feedback from the Course Convenor and/or Supervisors will be provided to at the review meeting.  Written feedback will also be provided within 10 working days of the review meeting.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"235aa9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"235ae9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6f5aa9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"7f5ae9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ab5aa9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"bb5ae9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e75ae9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"f75ae9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"935aa9ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"PEP log book & evaluation","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Log book contains notations of activities as well as reflections on learning through lectures and workshops as part of professional development. Students are required as part of PEP6 to provide an evaluation of the program – what worked, what didn’t – and any recommendations.  There is no format or length expectation.  Marks and feedback will be provided by the Course Convenor/Clinic Director to students within 10 working days of submission.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PSYC7423","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSYC7423 - Assessment in Forensic Psychology","description":"

This course teaches students about standardised tests and procedures used by psychologists to evaluate intellectual, cognitive and adaptive functioning, as well as psychological tests used to evaluate general psychological functioning. Emphasis will be placed on tests typically used by forensic psychologists in forensic contexts.  

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e18c853c1bce2410d5fb0fabdc4bcbd2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Weschler test marking and report","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will be provided a case study and an unscored Weschler profile. They will be required to correctly score, interpret and write the ‘test results’ area of a cognitive report. 2500 words.  Marks and feedback will be provided by the Course Convenor/Clinic Director to students within 10 working days of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e58c853c1bce2410d5fb0fabdc4bcbd3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f18c853c1bce2410d5fb0fabdc4bcbd4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f18c853c1bce2410d5fb0fabdc4bcbd5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f18c853c1bce2410d5fb0fabdc4bcbd6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f98c853c1bce2410d5fb0fabdc4bcbd4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f98c853c1bce2410d5fb0fabdc4bcbd5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"798c853c1bce2410d5fb0fabdc4bcbd7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Test administration vivas","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"0","description":"

All students need to meet the criterion of complete competency in test administration. This will be assessed individually. Individual WAISIV vivas to be organised after Week 4 and before Week 8. This is a pass/fail component. Students must demonstrate mastery of the test. Failure to pass this component will be considered a failure of the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f98c853c1bce2410d5fb0fabdc4bcbd5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8e9e7f691bc2e410d5fb0fabdc4bcbb1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Test battery","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will be provided a case study and be required to identify a reasonable and valid set of tests that will efficiently and effectively address specific referral question.  2500 words.  Marks and written feedback will be provided by the Course Convenor/Clinic Director to students within 10 working days of submission.

contentlets.description: This course teaches students about standardised tests and procedures used by psychologists to evaluate intellectual, cognitive and adaptive functioning, as well as psychological tests used to evaluate general psychological functioning. Emphasis will be placed on tests typically used by forensic psychologists in forensic contexts.
contentlets.title: Assessment in Forensic Psychology

contentlets.description: This course takes a scientist-practitioner approach, linking a framework of how psychological intervention works. A strong emphasis will be placed on links between research and clinical practice and how one informs the other.
contentlets.title: Forensic Interventions 1

The course provides theoretical knowledge and practical skills in in working with forensic populations, with consideration to the relevant social context, including some of the systemic issues that confront vulnerable populations.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"58515686db37e050fe4b322af49619df","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Case intervention plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will prepare one written case intervention plan (2500 words). This will require students to plan an assessment and intervention for a child and/or family, in the context of the relevant literature and in consideration of ethical and practice issues. Marks and feedback will be provided by the Course Convenor/Clinic Director to students within 10 working days of submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"14515686db37e050fe4b322af49619e1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"14515686db37e050fe4b322af49619e2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"18515686db37e050fe4b322af49619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1c515686db37e050fe4b322af49619e1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2c515686db37e050fe4b322af49619f5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

One hour group presentation on ethical and professional intervention considerations for particular forensic group.  Classes will be divided into small groups; each group will identify a particular forensic population and provide a presentation on ethical and professional intervention issues related to a particular forensic population, including identification of appropriate forensic measures.   

\n

Verbal feedback will be provided by colleagues and Course Convenor following the presentation.  Marks and written feedback will be provided by the Course Convenor/Clinic Director to students within 10 working days of submission.

Students are required to complete an empirical research project under the supervision of a member of academic staff in the School of Psychology which is written up as a thesis in the form of a journal article. Research projects may be carried out on any topic that is relevant to forensic psychology.


The thesis and research project are assessed across three courses – Thesis 1, Thesis 2 and Thesis 3 – in which students would normally be expected to enrol for terms 1 to 3 respectively.  In addition, students are required to complete a series of Research Methods Workshops (normally 5 or 6 workshops across the year) to support and develop the research skills necessary to undertake the thesis and to work as a scientist practitioner after graduation. Refer to the Research Thesis section of the Master of Psychology (Forensic) Program Guide available on the School website https://www.psy.unsw.edu.au/current-students/postgraduate-coursework/master-psychology-forensic.


PSYC7426 is the first course in the three-course sequence.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"195a69ffdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961980","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"100","description":"

PSYC7426 Thesis 1 is the first in a three-course sequence, which together assess students’ performance on the research project and thesis. In order to pass Thesis 1 and progress to PSYC7427 Thesis 2 students must prepare and present a satisfactory research proposal, including an indicative timeline for their research. This proposal is presented to the Forensic Masters research panel for approval. Additionally, students must attend all Research Methods Workshops associated with this course to be marked as ‘Satisfactory’.

\n

By the end of the term, students must write a brief progress report which describes progress relative to the timeline contained in their approved proposal, and notes any significant changes to topic or methodology. This progress report must be approved by both the thesis supervisor and the Program Director before students can progress to Thesis 2. If adequate progress has been made on the project, students will receive a grade of EC (Enrolment Continuing) for Thesis 1 and will be allowed to progress to Thesis 2. Similarly, if students meet the requirements of Thesis 2 they will be permitted to progress to PSYC7428 Thesis 3. Students will, while enrolled in Thesis 3, submit their completed thesis and present their findings at the Annual UNSW Forensic Psychology research Conference.

\n

The completed thesis is marked by two members of the School's academic staff. The supervisor is not involved in marking the thesis. The conference presentation is a requirement of course completion but is not formally assessed. Once a thesis mark is confirmed for Thesis 3 it will be backfilled to both Thesis 1 and Thesis 2 to stand alongside the EC grades.
